SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

NO. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

ANSWERING THE QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person

It is difficult to answer a general questionnaire or pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another.

Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. If it's impossible for you to answer the question, just leave it blank.

The object of asking it here is not to collect answers to answer the questions, they should write them on separate pieces of paper and send them to us separately.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate pieces of paper and send them to us separately.

Western Canadian Pioneers' Diary is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires

( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer education and employment
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Board,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

PIONEER EXPERIENCE: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences or memories. Some of the questions may not apply to your particular situation; others may be impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about answering them all. If you can't answer a question, give as much detail as possible, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the question.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914 and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or supply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled Pioneer Life, will be sent to you if you are willing to answer this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here.

Western Canadian Pioneers' Estate is still being prepared at a later date. Some of these may interest you, and you will be sent to you.

All questionnaires:

Pioneer health conditions
Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
Pioneer education and churchwork
Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, that is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: JAMES BEAN
2. Your address: A.A.M.F.D.A.
3. Date: JAN. 19, 1953.
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): PETERBOROUGH ONT.
5. What was your father's name and occupation? EDWARD EMMERSON FARMER.
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): MAR. 29, 1892
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: MIRAMICHI NEW BRUNSWICK TO SASKATCHEWAN.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or if you were a small child, "I was in my teens", etc.), age 28
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   In those early days of Ontario farming was too small for our family and prices were too high to buy land.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?).
    From friends who had already come out, coming to Western Canada was a great adventure in those days dating back to the North West Rebellion and earlier.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

13. What means of transportation did you use?

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Family

A small boy full of life than during a night and within found was walking up to teach and to sound education who to our boys and also a child of R.R. conductor and schoolmaster fulfilling its turn.

Gone from Calgary to farm near it myself

Alberta has decided. April 12 wrote it to myself

Having a very heavy snow storm

Recorded at Almada No. 200
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Putting it clearly some often thought we were crazy.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

Our family and several other friends and neighbors traveled together in a wagon purchased in 1891.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Train from Peterboro to Oxford.

14. What incidents of the journey west do you remember? (People you met on the way, accidents or other excitement, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, etc.)

A small boy fell off the team during the night and when found was walking up to teach following the team after a shift of R.R. conductors and employees also a general excitement when the strike broke out.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Arrived from Oxford to farm north of where Alameda first landed. About 12 miles north of Regina.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Sheridan 19. 4. 2. 18

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Resided at Alameda, then moved.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Farming.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle? If so, do not know.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

25. What was your occupation?
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Weekly.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

James Bean Dec 24, 1895

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? If so, where did they settle?

We all came together.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.

23. In the early part of pioneer days that stands out in your memory was almost always an open well. Also it would be hard getting our cattle effects across river. Creek would be unflooded stage.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Visited friends and went to church quite regularly. Two horses or mules. Horse vehicle was once two horses or mules.
25. When was the first car used in the community?

26. If you owned a car before 1947, when did you buy it? What makes it?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appear-

ing, better means of travel, etc.)

29. How often did you shop in the early days? Which about four times

30. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogue?

31. What kind of relations did you buy by this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order.

32. What did you first order?

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision? You can name two and perhaps three in addition and so they could be acquired. We added our farm and all our belongings in Alberta and we had nothing to go back to.

Would you have to own anything in 1908-1919?

32. When did you last have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision? You can name two and perhaps three in addition and so they could be acquired. We added our farm and all our belongings in Alberta and we had nothing to go back to.
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   - Yes, we had a car by 1914; when did you buy it? What makes?
27. Where was your trading center?
   - New for from your house?
28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any charges due to new terms appear-
   ing.)
   - Yes. The end of 1913 was at Debarr when we
   arrived in the country but this was finished to Baldwin
   during the summer of 1912 and trains ran pule
   regularly thereafter.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   - We lived about four miles from
   Alameda and could purchase all supplies as needed.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district start going to town regularly
   on Saturdays?
   - We always had the produce on our district
   to fetch into town on Saturday morning

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogue?
   - What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction or
   purchases made by mail order each year by placing in the proportion of
   (one never purchased much through mail order because
   a great deal of the produce was even by barter)
   Butter eggs Beef - Pork - and vegetables turned
   in at stores for credit - we used to get from first to
   ten cents per dozen for eggs Butter at one time sold
   for ten cents per pound, the first order for
   five pounds of fresh milk was sold for 37 cents
   arranged chickens delivered ready for the oven - family
   spring hams per pound, brand pork per pound
   six cents per pound

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   - Rural telephone too was organized in 1915-1919

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying
   permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you
   make this decision?
   - Yes we came here and bought land and
   took up homestead so near to the settlement
   as they could be acquired, we sold our farm
   and all our belongings in Ontario and so had
   nothing to go back to
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Yes during the early years there were constantly someone coming and going, taking up homesteads and afterwards moving away without getting title to their land. Some "pulled out" for pure curiosity.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

A few people left the district but not many. Most of people had nothing to move with. We organized straw-baling crews and went wherever we could get surplus straw and had it shipped in by car loads.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My brother W.W. Emmerson held a position as municipal councillor for about 8 years from 1924. Several other members held positions as S.S. superintendents, secretaries of different organizations, presidents of Agricultural societies.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

My father EDWARD EMMERSON purchased the first lot of lumber in the new town of Alameda and my sister Mrs A.D. Tarrant was the first person to get mail in the first Office at Alameda. 1892. A small county P.O. led life in operation for quite a few years since about 1882. (Alameda)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

The name Alameda is supposed to have been started by the wife of the first settler to locate near the junction of the Moose creek and the Souris River. This name was Broyer and his wife named it after Alameda California then the Post Office was established and took the same name and when the Railroad came in the name still stuck. Osbow got its name owing to the curve of the Souris River which resembles an Oxbow over...
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1920? What reasons did they have for moving? Yes, during the early years there was constantly someone coming and going, taking up homesteads and afterwards moving away without getting title to them. Some people left the district - that not many more of people had nothing to move with. We organized straw bailers, co-ops and tried to organize in to be leaders.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

36. To you or any organization, mention if you have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates whenever possible.

My Brother William Emmerson lived a position as promised. In April 8 years post 1894

37. If you or any of your family or friends were farmers to have or do something in the district, please list their names and what they did. (Such as owner, tenant, etc.)

Edward Emerson homesteaded 160 acres in the town of Alameda. He married Miss Ada Brown in 1892, and moved to the town of Alameda. 1892. A month after, 1892 (Alameda)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School district, Post offices, Villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) the date of the settlement, (2) any changes in names since the first names were given, (3) the date of the settlement, combining existing places names, (4) the date of the settlement, combining existing places names, (5) the date of the settlement, combining existing places names.

The name Alameda is supposed to have been started by the wife of the first settler to locate near the Junction of the Mora creek and the San Joaquin River. Her name was Barbara and her husband named it after Alameda, Italy, then the first office was established and took the name Alameda. However, the railroad came to the name of the San Joaquin River which resembled the name of the town of Alameda.

Ada Brown
Boccaccio got the name in the same way from the Latin words Boce and Boccio = Bow.
Boscurvis got its name in the same way from the Latin words Bos - ox, and Curvis - a Bow

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

I have one son and one daughter.

Our son occupies our home farm since we retired to live in Alameda. Our daughter is living with us in town.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

Our first plowing was done with two horses and a walking plow then we graduated to sulky plows drawn by two or three horses then two or three furrow plow drawn by six or seven horses. The next step was tractor and power machinery some predict that soon we will be operating power machinery drawn by aeroplanes.
